conclusion: The v-t graphs represent two objects, A and B, moving in the same direction along a straight line.

The vertical axis represents velocity (v), the horizontal axis represents time (t), Curve A (upper curve) shows the velocity of object A over time, and Curve B (lower curve) shows the velocity of object B over time.
The question asks if the difference in speed between objects A and B is continuously increasing from 0 to t₁.
The difference in speed at any time t is Δv(t) = v_A(t) - v_B(t), and for it to be continuously increasing, d(Δv)/dt > 0 throughout the interval.
At t = 0, there is a small initial difference in velocity; at some intermediate time, the difference has increased; at t = t₁, the difference appears larger than at the start.

Curve A appears to have a steeper initial slope than Curve B. Both curves reach their maximum heights and then begin to decrease. The difference between the curves increases until both curves reach their peaks and then begins to decrease as they approach t₁.
The difference in velocity increases initially but then begins to decrease as both objects start slowing down.
The difference in speed is not continuously increasing throughout the interval from 0 to t₁. It increases for a portion of the interval and then begins to decrease.
No, the difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing throughout the time interval from 0 to t₁.
